paper.title: A communication-privacy tradeoff for modular addition

author.org: Department of Computer Science, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel
Aiken Computation Laboratory, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA

paper.abstract: We consider the following problem: A set of n parties, each holding an input value xi∈{0, 1,…,m−1}, wishes to distributively compute the sum of their input values modulo the integer m, (i.e, ∑ni=1xi mod m). The parties wish to compute this sum t-privately. That is, in a way that no coalition of size at most t can infer any additional information, other than what follows from their input values and the computed :[72],"present an oblivious protocol which computes the sum t-privately, using n·⌈(t+1)/2⌉ messages. This protocol requires fewer messages than the known private protocols for modular addition. Then, we show that this protocol is in a sense optimal, by proving a tight lower bound of ⌈n·(t+1)/2⌉ messages for any oblivious protocol that computes the sum t-privately.
